document_data.name: Sewers of Ravens Bluff
document_data.mainbody:
The '''sewers of Ravens Bluff''' were a sanitation system of pipe and tunnel networks beneath the city.

{{Quote|All things being equal, I'd much rather be stuck for six months mapping the sewers of Ravens Bluff than spend a single season on the [[Moonsea]].|[[Mendryll Belarod]]<ref>}}

Structure.Sewer Ecology: [[Crocodile]]s, [[mice]], [[rat]]s, [[giant rat]]s, and [[otyugh]]s were known to inhabit the sewers.<ref>{{Cite organized play/LC/Luck Takes a Vacation|9}} As well as a variety of other crawling and flying [[vermin]].

Groups of Interest.[[Church of Beshaba]]: A group of [[Beshaban]]s operated a shrine to their goddess in the sewers in the mid-14{{th}} century [[DR]], known as the "Shrine of Misfortune",<ref>{{Cite organized play/LC/Luck Takes a Vacation|2,9}} until a group of adventurers destroyed it in [[1368 DR]].<ref>{{Cite organized play/LC/Luck Takes a Vacation|12}}{{LCRB}}
Groups of Interest.City Watch (Ravens Bluff)|City Watch: One of the nine branches of the City Watch was the Sewer Brigade. They dealt with unusual monsters and smuggling operations.<ref>
Groups of Interest.Cult of the Raven: The Cult of the Raven sometimes had their secret meetings within the city's sewers.<ref>
Groups of Interest.Yarvander: The noble family [[Yarvander]] helped [[drow]] have a chance to covertly view society in Ravens Bluff, such as by means of the city's sewers.<ref>

document_data.Rumors & Legends:
* Some [[bard]]ic songs claimed that [[jewelry]] stolen from [[Myth Drannor]] in its dying days was hidden within the sewers.
* Several patrons sighted spectral visions of [[beholder]]s within the sewers, which at least one [[mage]] suggested could be a visible manifestation of [[Scrying (spell)|''scrying'']] by some other mage in the city.<ref>
document_data.Trivia:
* The civic officials in Ravens Bluff were notoriously reluctant to make [[map]]s of the city's sewers publicly available, fearing they would be used for illicit purposes.<ref> Though the [[Hawksblood Hall]] and the [[Raven Museum]] both had maps of the sewers.<ref> And the [[Mapper's Workshop]] sold both partial and comprehensive maps of the sewers.{{Cite organized play/LC/A Good Day To Die|28}}
* [[Sigird Sigirdson]], a thief, had an intimate knowledge of the hiding places of Ravens Bluff, including the sewers.<ref>{{Cite polyhedron/91/The Living City: The Swineherd's House|19}}
